TopicTitle: Put a confirmation of exit on alt-F4, or change alt-F5

Articles.Content:
Pretty obvious one that's been mentioned before but with three patches in a week I figure this is pretty easy to add to the next one.

Alt-F5 for quicksave right next to alt-F4 for quit without confirmation is not the brightest idea ever. A quit confirmation on alt-F4 or a change to the bind for a named quicksave seems almost too obvious to require suggesting, but... here we are.
No need to hold alt when quick saving.
Alt+F5 allows you to create a named quicksave. F5 without alt creates the default quicksave.

No need to hold alt when quick saving.

If you want multiple quicksaves, there is.
Yes, please. Changing the quicksave key to F6 would probably be the easiest solution, I think Alt-F4 would bypass a confirmation dialog.
More easily accomplished by swapping the keybind to ctrl+f5. alt+f4 is a windows keybind that force closes whatever you've got attention on. I don't think there IS a way to add a confirmation to it.

Alt+F5 allows you to create a named quicksave. F5 without alt creates the default quicksave.

Didn't know that. Interesting.

More easily accomplished by swapping the keybind to ctrl+f5. alt+f4 is a windows keybind that force closes whatever you've got attention on. I don't think there IS a way to add a confirmation to it.

When a program is running it listens for windows messages (events) such as mouse clicks, keyboard input, etc. This is known as the message loop.

An application can choose to intercept and handle any events sent to it while it has the focus, or it can ignore them. In the case of alt-F4, the program can listen for it and handle it, or let it go and have the OS handle it.

Starcraft, for example, handles the alt-F4 input with a confirmation dialog for exit, and many editor programs of various kinds will prompt the user with an option to save their work when alt F4 is pressed. For now I have autohotkey set to deal with the issue, but not everyone is going to be comfortable using that.
